milestones.title: Cuneiform
milestones.caption: Sumerians in Mesopotamia created pictograms called Cuneform.

milestones.title: Hanja
milestones.caption: The Chinese writing system was used initially when Gojoseon (modern day Korea) was founded.

milestones.title: Hieroglyphs
milestones.caption: Egyptians developed pictograms called Hieroglyphs. Each Hieroglyph was a visual representation of a word.

milestones.title: Phoenician
milestones.caption: Phoenicians in Egypt developed an alphabet where characters represented sounds rather than objects.

milestones.title: Greek & Roman
milestones.caption: Greeks adopted Phoenician and added a few vowels. Then, the Romans refined it to create the alphabet we use today.

milestones.title: Idu
milestones.caption: Modified Hanja with simplified characters representing Korean words and sounds. Idu combines the Hyangchai and Gugyeol systems of writing.

milestones.title: Carolingian
milestones.caption: The King of the Franks, Charlemagne, could not handle disorder and hired a man from York to create orderly, legible type with upper/lower case letters; it was called Carolingian script.

milestones.title: Hangul
milestones.caption: King Sejong created the original Korean letters used today and released them in his speech Hunmin Jeong-eum (The Proper Sounds for the Education of the People).

milestones.title: Metal
milestones.caption: The invention of Gutenberg printing press and metal type initiated the revolution of machine made typography.

milestones.title: Yeonsangun
milestones.caption: The new Hangul letters were so easy to learn that the aristocrats feared their corruption would be revealed, and their power taken away, by the newly literate. King Yeonsangun joined this opposition and banned Hangul due to it’s use by the lower class to ridicule him.

milestones.title: Renaissance
milestones.caption: The French designed a simplified style of type with less influence from the scribe’s handwriting than its predecessors.

milestones.title: Hangul
milestones.caption: Hangul was officially used again after going through a revival 100 years prior. Bourgeois used Hanja as an attempt to keep the gap between classes.

milestones.title: Realist
milestones.caption: William Caslon IV started the trend of the sans serif, it quickly caught on. The sans serif was a simplified style that rid of the serifs at the ends of each letter.

milestones.title: Japanese
milestones.caption: Japan colonized Korea and implemented Japanese as the official language. Hangul was officially banned thirty-one years later due to cultural assimilation.

milestones.title: Modernist
milestones.caption: Modernist typography was popularized in Germany at the Bauhaus. This tyle of type was influenced by geometric forms.

milestones.title: Korean
milestones.caption: Korea regained independence and Hangul once again became the official written language. Three years after, North Korea banned the use of Hanja.

milestones.title: Post
milestones.caption: Post-modern type emerged as a reaction against the Modernist movement. The invention of the computer influenced the creation of unconventional letters.
